readings: Japan at War (Sources of Modern China, pp. 316-333)
Oral Histories of the Comfort Women

readingAnalyses.title: Japan at War
readingAnalyses.author: Various primary sources
readingAnalyses.source: Sources of Modern China / Japanese Tradition
readingAnalyses.summary:
These documents reveal the ideology and experience of Japan's fifteen-year war in Asia (1931-1945). Official rhetoric proclaimed Japan's mission to 'liberate' Asia from Western colonialism under the banner of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. Soldiers' accounts reveal both the indoctrination that made aggression seem righteous and the brutal reality of warfare against civilian populations.

The gap between rhetoric and reality is striking. Japan claimed to free Asia while exploiting it; promised prosperity while extracting resources; spoke of liberation while committing atrocities. Understanding how intelligent people came to believe these contradictions—and how some came to see through them—is essential for understanding not just Japanese history but how war propaganda works.

keyQuotes.quote: We were told we were liberating Asia. We believed it.
The Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere would free Asian peoples from Western imperialism.
What we did in China... I cannot speak of it even now.

thematicExamples: Official propaganda vs. soldier experience - gap between what was claimed and what was done
Dehumanization of enemies - how ordinary soldiers committed atrocities
Postwar reckoning - Japanese veterans struggling to understand their actions
Co-Prosperity Sphere as cover for exploitation - liberation rhetoric hiding economic extraction
realLifeConnections: How propaganda works - lessons applicable to understanding any wartime rhetoric
Veteran trauma and silence - patterns seen in many postwar societies
Japanese history textbook controversies - ongoing debates about how to teach the war
War crimes and accountability - Nuremberg/Tokyo trials and their limits

readingAnalyses.title: Oral Histories of the Comfort Women
readingAnalyses.author: Survivor testimonies
readingAnalyses.summary:
The 'comfort women' testimonies document one of the war's worst atrocities: the systematic sexual enslavement of women by the Japanese military. Estimates suggest 50,000-200,000 women, mostly Korean but also Chinese, Filipino, Dutch, and others, were forced into military brothels. Survivors remained silent for decades; only in the 1990s did they begin speaking publicly.

These testimonies are difficult to read but essential. They document kidnapping, confinement, repeated rape, and physical abuse. They also document survival, resistance, and the courage required to speak decades later. The ongoing disputes over comfort women memorials and Japanese government apologies show how unresolved historical trauma continues to poison regional relations.

CONTENT WARNING: These readings contain descriptions of sexual violence. Students should be prepared for disturbing content.

keyQuotes.quote: I was not a 'comfort woman.' I was a sex slave.
For fifty years I could not speak. The shame was unbearable.
I want the Japanese government to acknowledge what they did to us.

thematicExamples: Military sexual violence as systematic policy - not individual crimes but organized system
Decades of silence - shame, trauma, and social stigma prevented survivors from speaking
Demands for recognition - survivors seeking acknowledgment, not just compensation
Contested memory - Japan and Korea dispute facts, responsibility, and appropriate response
realLifeConnections: Ongoing Japan-Korea disputes over comfort women memorials and government statements
Wartime sexual violence as weapon - patterns seen in conflicts worldwide
Survivor-centered approaches to historical justice - listening to those who experienced atrocities
Statute of limitations on historical crimes - when does accountability expire?

overallSynthesis:
These readings bring us face-to-face with the human cost of the nationalism and imperialism we've studied abstractly. Tokutomi Sohō's Social Darwinism (Plate 17) and Fukuzawa's 'Leaving Asia' (Plate 12) provided intellectual justification for empire; these documents show what empire actually meant for its victims.

The comfort women testimonies are particularly important because they challenge both Japanese denial and the abstraction of 'historical atrocities.' These were individual women with names and lives, violated systematically by a state that claimed to be liberating Asia. Their survival and eventual testimony represent a form of resistance that outlasted the empire itself.

The ongoing disputes over comfort women—memorials erected and removed, apologies made and retracted, historical facts denied and reaffirmed—show that this history isn't 'past.' Korean anger and Japanese defensiveness continue to shape regional relations. Understanding why this issue remains so contentious requires understanding what happened, why it remained suppressed so long, and what genuine reconciliation might require.

CONTENT NOTE: These are emotionally difficult readings. Students should be prepared for disturbing content and supported in processing it.
executiveSummary:
Japan's fifteen-year war in Asia (1931-1945) caused immense suffering: millions dead in China, Korea colonized and exploited, Southeast Asia occupied. The 'comfort women' system—military sexual slavery—represents one of the war's most horrific aspects. These readings bring us face-to-face with both the ideology that drove Japanese aggression and the human cost of that aggression.

The comfort women testimonies are difficult to read but essential. These women, mostly Korean but also Chinese, Filipino, Dutch, and others, were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese military. Their stories remained suppressed for decades; only in the 1990s did survivors begin speaking out. The ongoing disputes over comfort women memorials show how unresolved historical trauma continues to poison Japan-Korea relations.

keyQuestions.question: How did Japan justify its empire, and how did that justification compare to Western imperialism?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Japan claimed to liberate Asia from the West. But Japan's rule was equally (or more) brutal. The ideology was self-serving—Pan-Asianism served Japanese interests. Compare to Western 'civilizing mission' rhetoric.

keyQuestions.question: Why did the comfort women remain silent for so long, and what changed in the 1990s?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Shame, stigma, disbelief. Cold War politics muted criticism of Japan (US ally). Korean democratization and women's movements enabled testimony. Kim Hak-sun's 1991 testimony broke the silence.

keyQuestions.question: How should we think about responsibility and reconciliation for wartime atrocities?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Japan has apologized (sort of)—but politicians keep undercutting apologies. Victims want official acknowledgment and compensation. Compare to Germany's approach to Holocaust memory.
